/For providers/Making a notification to the Health Ombudsman

Making a notification to the Health Ombudsman

Complete a notification form

This includes receiving notifications from health practitioners, employers and educators, relating to the health, conduct or performance of registered and unregistered health practitioners and students.

Download notification form

Registered health practitioners notifications

For registered health practitioners, notifications fall into three categoriesâ€”mandatory, voluntary and self-notificationsâ€”as defined in the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law (Queensland) (the National Law).

Read more

Unregistered health practitioners notifications

Unregistered health practitioners must notify the Health Ombudsman if they form the reasonable belief that another healthcare worker has placed or is placing clients at serious risk of harm, in accordance with the National Code of Conduct for Health Care Workers (Queensland). The Health Ombudsman has the ability to take action against unregistered health practitioners in a variety of ways.

Read more

Related pages

What happens when the OHO receives a complaint?

When the Office of the Health Ombudsman receives a complaint, we will decide whether to accept the complaint, generally within 7 days.

How to resolve complaints and concerns

We always recommend, where appropriate, that complainants discuss their concerns with the health service provider first. This is often the quickest and easiest way to address any concerns or fix a problem.

A list of commonly asked questions by health providers and practitioners.
